Article: Most U.S. consumers, swept into the era of Big Data, in a prosperous nation where Google, Apple, Facebook and Amazon have become the definition of Big Business, donât readily dwell on the constitutional complexities of personal privacy.Â  One of my friends on Facebook (yes, I use Facebook) posted a message last Thursday: âWhy is anyone surprised that Facebook sells data about its users? Thatâs their entire business!â My colleague Rick Merritt also penned an op-ed  pointing out: âTraders may pound Facebook, stock and regulators may draw up rules for online privacy, but the Pandora's box of big data is forever open.âÂ  TouchÃ©. I reckon that the popular sentiment is that privacy train left the station a long time ago. We already feel powerless. Itâs easier to give up than fight it, because after all, no one has the individual power to cram Pandora back into her box. Not everyone in the world, however, feels that way. If Europeâs new General Data Protection Regulation, GDPR, is any indication, Europeans are serious about giving back to citizens and residents control over their own personal data. Europe will start enforcing the GDPR next month.Â  Digital sovereignty  Curiously, many regulators and consumer activists in Europe have framed their privacy discussions as a matter of âdigital sovereigntyâÂ â a term rarely uttered in the United States. Last Thursday, Emmanuel Macron, president of France, laid out a new strategy for artificial intelligence in his country. The French government will spend 1.5 billion euro ($1.85 billion) over five years to support research in the field, encourage startups, and collect data that can be used and shared by engineers.Â  Macronâs goal is obvious. France is figuring out that theyâve got to start catching up to the U.S. and China. He wants the best and the brightest in the AI field to come to Paris. #AIforhumanity (Source: Tweet by Emmanuel Macron on March 30, 2018)  To most American observers, Macronâs economic argument is easy to understand. Just like President Trump wants to see more manufacturing jobs hereÂ â such as inviting Foxconn to open up a factory in WisconsinÂ â Macron wants AI brains in Paris. Copy that. Where things get tricky for most Americans to comprehend is the French argument on âvalues.âÂ  Talking to Wired magazine in an interview that occurred right after his speech, Macron argued that France needs to be part of the AI revolution because the French need to see their âvaluesâ reflected in the way data is collected, used and protected. He said: âWhen you look at artificial intelligence today, the two leaders are the U.S. and China. In the US, it is entirely driven by the private sector, large corporations, and some startups dealing with them. All the choices they will make are private choices that deal with collective valuesâ¦ On the other side, Chinese players collect a lot of data driven by a government whose principles and values are not ours. And Europe has not exactly the same collective preferences as the U.S. or China.â This is where Macron introduces âdigital sovereignty.â He said: If we want to defend our way to deal with privacy, our collective preference for individual freedom versus technological progress, integrity of human beings and human DNA, if you want to manage your own choice of society, your choice of civilization, you have to be able to be an acting part of this AI revolution. Thatâs the condition of having a say in designing and defining the rules of AI. That is one of the main reasons why I want to be part of this revolution and even to be one of its leaders. I want to frame the discussion at a global scale.  Well said. In many ways, while U.S. consumers, corporations and even our own government persist in laissez-faire attitudes toward our privacy while hoping for the best, Macron is taking a stand on this very issue thatâs not purely altruistic. Besides protecting his people from unwelcome cyber-snooping, he sees an opportunity to leapfrog the U.S. in a critical technological competition. The President of France stressed, âAI will raise a lot of issues in ethics, in politics, it will question our democracy.â The question is what weâre going to do about it. Silicon Valleyâs value?   As Iâve covered the tech industry in Silicon Valley over the years, Iâve often observed a tendency for seemingly disinterested observers (like me) to be mesmerized by each huge technological leap the engineering community has made. But what sort of social values has Silicon Valley engineered?Â  Other than believing in the marketâs invisible hand and that less regulation is always better, the engineering community leans toward an eerie silence about the social implications of their own products and technologies. The only time most Valley types speak out on such issues is to disparageÂ critics who suggest that technology might have social implications. Earlier this year, I had a chance to chat with a whole bunch of data scientists working at platform companies like Linkedin, Amazon and Ancestry.com in California. Because the conversation was held over a private dinner, I wonât be able to quote any of the people present. But they generally confided that Europeâs upcoming GDPR âis what we all talk about all the time these days.â Really? You guys are all worried about GDPR? Hell yes, they said.  The GDPR applies not only to companies based in the EU, but any organization anywhere that collects or processes personal data inside the EU. According to the European Commission, “personal data is any information relating to an individual, whether it relates to his or her private, professional or public life. It can be anything from a name, a home address, a photo, an email address, bank details, posts on social networking websites, medical information, or a computerâs IP address.â The GDPR is a big deal for U.S.-based platform companies because they not only have to comply, but also because the U.S. has no equivalent regulation. This lack of regulatory harmony leaves a lot of gray area. What if a Danish citizen traveling to the U.S. posts a picture of himself on Facebook, but later decides to take it down? According to the GDPR, he has a âright to be forgottenâ (or âright to erasureâ). No such right exists on Facebook in the United States. One data scientist told me, âFrankly, most big platform companies in the U.S. are waiting to be sued before taking any actionâ on such privacy issues.Â  When I asked if there is anything that data scientists can do proactively to protect individualsâ data privacyÂ â whether the individuals are in the United States or in Europe â the answer was firm no. âUnless there are regulations, there is not much we can do.âÂ  This is a classic case of technology advancing far ahead of legislation. Most corporations, let alone engineers â who tend to be distrustful of politics â are loath to lay a fingers on thorny issues like this.Â  Am I too idealistic to suggest that it might be high time for U.S. citizens to define and articulate our privacy preferences and our own values?Â  Just because we can do certain things with the awesome technologies weâve developed, that doesnât mean we should use them. As Isaac Asimov often asked, are we the master, or are we the machine? Macron said during the interview, âThe key driver should not only be technological progress, but human progressâ¦ I do believe that Europe is a place where we are able to assert collective preferences and articulate them with universal values.â Let that sink in for a minute.Â  â Junko Yoshida, Chief International Correspondent, EE Times
